STATE OF MICHIGAN
DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
GRETCHEN WHITMER
LANS ING
ELIZABETH HERTEL
GOVERNOR DIRECTOR
November 2, 2023
Jamea Perlaki
Traverse Place
512 S. Grand Traverse St.,
FLINT, MI, 48502-1207
Re: License #: CB250201474
Dear Mr. Perlaki:
Attached is the Interim Inspection Report for the above referenced agency completed on
10/27/2023. An Exit Conference was held with the agency on 10/27/2023. Due to the
violations of applicable licensing rules, a written corrective action plan is required. The
corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and must include the
following:
• For any repeat violations, why the prior corrective action plan did not result
in compliance.
• How compliance with each citation will be achieved.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action plan.
• Specific time frames for each citation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
• How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
• The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you fail to submit an acceptable corrective action plan, disciplinary action may result.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact the area manager at 517-899-6024.
P.O. BOX 30650 • LANSING, MICHIGAN 48909
www.michigan.gov • (517) 335-1980

Sincerely,
Lonia Perry Calloway, Licensing Consultant
MDHHS\Division of Child Welfare Licensing
4th Floor, Suite 4B
51111 Woodward Avenue
Pontiac, MI 48342
(248) 860-3317
enclosure

III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS
The agency is in compliance with all applicable rules and statutes except for the following:
CPA Rule 400.12503 Policy and procedures.
(2) The policies and procedures must cover at least all
the following areas:
(k) Termination.
The agency requires a 90-day and180-day follow up with youths following the
youth’s discharge from the program.
Three of four closed independent living youth records reviewed did not show
compliance:
• One record showed the 90-day follow up was due by 3/5/2023 and completed
late on 5/12/2023.
• A second record showed the 90-day follow up was due by 9/18/2023 and
completed late on 9/23/2023.
• A third record showed the 90-day follow up was due by 7/18/2023 and
completed late on 8/30/2023.
Repeat Violation- cited during the 2022 Renewal inspection, with a corrective
action plan approved on 10/13/2022.
CPA Rule 400.12509 Independent living record.
(3) The case record must contain all the following
information and documentation, which must be recorded
2

within 30 calendar days after placement in independent
living and updated at least once every 90 calendar days:
(o) Service plans as required in R 400.12419 and R
400.12420. If the youth has biological children, the
service plan must address the living arrangement for the
child or children, visitation/parenting time with the youth's
biological children or a clear explanation why this is not
possible or appropriate.
Two of eight service plans reviewed (related to one of three open independent living
youth records reviewed) were three and five days late respectively.
IV. TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE
The facility was offered technical assistance in the following areas:.
• Nothing this inspection
V. CONSULTATION
The facility was offered consultation in the following areas:
R400.12509(3)(o) Service plans.
The agency must gain a clearer understanding of the timeframe requirement for
each service plan period and how to accurately document this on the service
plan. I provided the agency with consultation in this area.
R400.12511(1) Termination.
The agency was advised consistently completing all areas of its discharge
documents might aid it in showing clearer compliance to the rule.
VI. EVALUATION OF PERIOD UNDER REVIEW
There were no substantiated incidents of maltreatment in care during this licensing
period.
There were no incidents of substantiated corporal punishment during this licensing
period.
Corrective Action Plan Compliance
The agency has submitted one acceptable corrective action plan during this
licensing period. The corrective action plan related to the agency’s 2022 Renewal
inspection where it received the following rule violations:
• R400.12212(3)(a) Personnel records.
• R400.12503(2)(j) Termination.
3

• R400.12510(2) Independence living record.
The agency made progress on this corrective action plan but was not totally
successful with all areas of the corrective action plan. The agency received one
repeat violation, as indicated in this inspection report.
Chief Administrator Assessment
The agency submitted a chief administrator's report dated 10/27/2023. The report
was completed as required by the rule. No areas of concern were noted.
Financial Overview
The agency submitted an annual budget, and a 9/30/2022 independent financial
audit, which did not show any areas of concern.
Staff and Youth Interviews
In addition to engaging with the program coordinator, and communication with the
chief administrator, I interviewed a case manager and two transitional youth
specialists. The staff reported positives about the agency’s program and the
efforts that are put forth to assist youths.
Three youths were interviewed. All the youths reported that the staff are
supportive, encouraging; and that the program works to help youth reach
independent living.
Description of Agency Walk Through
A walk though of the facility did not reveal any concerns or safety issues.
VII. FIELD ANALYST FINDINGS
Not applicable. This is an independent living program.
VIII. RECOMMENDATION
Based on inspection findings the agency is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, it
is recommended that the agency continue on their regular license.
October 29, 2023
________________________________________
Lonia Perry Calloway Date
Licensing Consultant
Approved By:
4
